captions.text: The ring must be taken deep into Mordor...
and cast back into the firey chasm from whence it came.
One of you must do this.
I have an idea that just might work.
Prepare yourself, Frodo!  We are almost there!
Gandalf, there is fire below us!
What the heck is going on?!
I'll tell you when it's over!  Just keep flying blasted bird!
Can you imagine what it would be like if we had walked the entire way?
Yeah one of us might have died!
It's funny because it's extremely far!

title: How Lord of The Rings Should Have Ended

comments.author: Anoni Mus

comments.text:
The problems with The Ring were:
1. It cannot be used by an elf/wizard -> it would eventually result in the 
carrier becoming a new Dark Lord
2. It cannot be cast away, because it has a way of finding it's way back to 
its master. It cannot stay in Rivendell or anywhere else, because Sauron's 
armies will probably eventually find it.
3. The West wouldn't take it - they don't intervene in the problems of 
Middle-Earth
4. It can only be destroyed in Mount Doom. Also, if succeeded, it would 
mean instantaneous defeat of Sauron (Mordor's structures will collapse, and 
Sauron lose his mind control over his armies).

So, they concluded that the best way of doing it would be sending it into 
Mordor by a non-immortal being (human/dwarf/hobbit), who wouldn't become a 
threat if he used the ring. Frodo volunteered, that seemed to be FATE to 
Gandalf (especially because he and Bilbo had proven to be very resistant to 
The Ring, and they are small and unnoticeble, making a hobbit the best one 
to sneak undetectably into Mordor).

I agree that using eagles is too dangerous: 1. There is a chance they 
wouldn't accept (they follow Manwe, who believes in Iluvatar's plans, who 
seems to favour the Fate of Frodo) 2. Sauron would probably expect an 
attack from Eagles, and send the fellbeasts against them

Some other ideas:
1. Using stone giants - nah, they probably wouldn't even understand what is 
wanted from them
2. Quickly finding and assembling the Army of the Dead
I think it's quite possible. "Even though not needing weapons, the weapons 
of the Enemy could not harm them." Send a portion of that army to conquer 
Mordor, and the other half to defeat Saruman. Although Sauron would notice 
such an army coming, and make for a run. Still, that would open a way for 
Frodo to walk into Mordor freely, having the dead bodyguarding him.
3. Using the power of Oath to overcome The Ring's sedative powers on its 
wearer
Feanor and his sons took an Oath so powerful, that they could never stop 
hunting for the Silmarils. If they failed to do so, then "o the everlasting 
Darkness doom us". The Oath bound them for centuries, and doomed them all.

Why not would Gandalf take an Oath like this: "I swear to allmighty 
Iluvatar, that I will use The Ring to destroy Sauron and Saruman; after 
their destruction make sure it is destroyed using Frodo; and I shall never 
use it against an elf/human/dwarf/hobbit/...; otherwise my body will perish 
instantly, and my spirit ripped out."

There is a strong chance the Oath would be strong enough to overcome The 
Ring, since it was given to Iluvatar, the God. And if it didn't, a 
disciplined mind like Gandalf's would still be strong enough to resist it 
until he has defeated both Sauron and Saruman, and then "become the next 
Dark Lord", as he said. But doing so, his body would perish instantly, just 
like happened to Sauron when Isildur cut off The Ring; and Frodo or sb that 
is constantly accompanying Gandalf and watching his every move, would pick 
The Ring up and destroy it.

The only question is whether Gandalf would make such a self-sacrifice (his 
spirit may remain evil even after The Ring is destroyed).

4. Using Palantirs (Denethor's/Saruman's) to mind control Sauron
If even Aragorn could resist to Sauron, then I'm sure that if the three 
elvish ringbearers united their powers, they would make Sauron their 
puppet, just like Saruman became Sauron's puppet. Although Sauron + 
Saruman's mind united would be a greater challenge. Still, they could have 
done it after Saruman was defeated.﻿

talk and would only help someone if they owed them a favor. This obviously 
couldn't have really been done this way, so calm down.﻿

comments.author: blippetyblip

comments.text:
OK. I read about Eagles ALL THE TIME! No, they could NOT call Eagles to 
help them with journey. Eagles are representation of ANGELS (go read 
what/who are Angels in Christianity since Tolkien represented Angels as 
Eagles in LOTR). So, now you will understand why you can't "just call 
Eagle" to fix stuff for you. From Christian perspective, Angels serve 
people but humans do not rule Angels (God does), they do help, but WE as 
people have to do OUR part in life to get somewhere. So, this is not a 
"bullshit journey", it is representation of our human life, with struggles, 
love, suffering etc. NOBODY can't make it "faster, easier etc.". 
Additionally please and read whole hierarchy of being in the LORT, then you 
will understand that Eagles are not "BIRDS" in Tolkien reality.﻿

comments.text:
The behaviour of the eagles reminded me of a harry potter quote: "Help will 
always be given at hogwarts to those who deserve it." That's how the eagles 
always behaved. I never saw them take commands. They provided help to those 
that deserved it the most. That's why they saved Frodo at the end and why 
they saved Gandalf and Thorin. They kind of appear just in time to tip the 
balance. They're not there to fight someone else's battles. They only get 
involved in the desperation of the deserving...not as a means of 
transportation. ﻿
